review.title: Modeling Attractiveness and Multiple Clicks in Sponsored Search Results
review.abstract: Click models are an important tool for leveraging user feedback, and are used by commercial search engines for surfacing relevant search results. However, existing click models are lacking in two aspects. First, they do not share information across search results when computing attractiveness. Second, they assume that users interact with the search results sequentially. Based on our analysis of the click logs of a commercial search engine, we observe that the sequential scan assumption does not always hold, especially for sponsored search results. To overcome the above two limitations, we propose a new click model. Our key insight is that sharing information across search results helps in identifying important words or key-phrases which can then be used to accurately compute attractiveness of a search result. Furthermore, we argue that the click probability of a position as well as its attractiveness changes during a user session and depends on the user's past click experience. Our model seamlessly incorporates the effect of externalities (quality of other search results displayed in response to a user query), user fatigue, as well as pre and post-click relevance of a sponsored search result. We propose an efficient one-pass inference scheme and empirically evaluate the performance of our model via extensive experiments using the click logs of a large commercial search engine.

sections.heading: 3.3 Inference
sections.text: Global parameters of our model include ηi and γi for i = 1,.., n. Furthermore, for each document d we must infer its attractiveness θd and post-click relevance ρd. Hyperparameters αη and Aγ are estimated from historical data, and the other parameters such as ηi, γi and ρd can be efficiently estimated by going through the click logs. For details, see Appendix A. Next, we will discuss a new method of calculating θd.

sections.heading: 3.4 Estimating Attractiveness
sections.text: A sponsored search result d, displayed in response to a q query, contains three components, namely a title, a description, and an ad URL. We use the following naive Bayes-like scheme to estimate the attractiveness: For each word w, with the exception of the frequently occurring stopwords that appear either in the title, description, or ad URL2, we calculate Nw the number of occurrences of w in Dq, and Nw the number of occurrences of w in the subset of Dq that received a click. For frequent queries (search volume less than 50 in a week window), we let Dq be the entire training corpus, while for frequent queries (occurring with a frequency of more than 50) we limit Dq to the documents that are displayed in response to q. Let us specify the number of words in d and estimate the number of words in d and estimate d = 1 | d | w | c = the occurrences of documents that we consider relevant.

sections.heading: 4. EXPERIMENTAL EVALUATION
sections.text: We collected three weeks of click logs from a major commercial search engine and used the data of the first week to calculate priorities, the data of the second week for training and the data of the third week for the test. We filter the data and keep only sessions in which at least one remote display was displayed. Our test setup is more like a real-world deployment scenario and differs somewhat from the usual practice of randomly splitting available data into a training and test set. In particular, we keep all queries in the test set, even if they were not observed in the training set. In this case, our estimate is based exclusively on priors compiled from the first data week. We put αγi + β γ i = 10 and α η i + β η i = 10. Table 1 summarizes our training data statistics. Note that for highly deceptive (> 1000) queries, there are significantly fewer three- and four-click sessions than for tail queries.

sections.heading: 4.1 Baselines
sections.text: For our experiments, we will compare the performance of our algorithm with the following four basic lines: 2For simplicity, the ad URL is treated as a single word.

sections.heading: 4.2 Evaluation Plan
sections.text: In the first part of our experimental evaluation, we are mainly interested in understanding how well our algorithm is able to infer the relevance after the click. Finally, this is the main motivation behind the study of click models. Since other models do not distinguish between attractiveness and relevance after the click, we will only compare our algorithm with the dynamic Bayesian network model (DBN) of [4]. Details of this experiment can be found in Section 4.3.For our second set of experiments (sections 4.4 to 4.8), we will focus on checking whether our model is capable of accurately predicting the sequence of user clicks. Click models are usually evaluated by calculating the average perplexity or closely related log probability on the test theorem. Remember that the perplexity for a single user session asp = 2 − 1 n ² n ² n = 1 Ci = 1 Ci log qi + (1 Ci) log + 1 (1) log qi (1) we will observe the probability of a log (1 − 19) where an observation of the Qi is made.

sections.heading: 4.3 Predicting Post-Click Relevance
sections.text: We have access to approximately 10,000 (query, ad) pairs from the test data set that have been classified as relevant or irrelevant by trained human editors. Note that human editors look into the landing pages to determine the labels. [4] In the following, we evaluate these (q, d) pairs using a score calculated by click relevance (attractiveness times by click relevance).The results for our model and DBN are shown in Figure 4. Our proposed model clearly exceeds DBN across all reminders. In particular, it should be noted that our model has high accuracy with low memory and is therefore capable of placing relevant documents higher on the list compared to DBN. Our model achieves an AUC of 0.8653 compared to DBN, which can only reach 0.7843.

sections.heading: 4.4 Predicting the First Clicked Ad
sections.text: This is a multi-class classification problem with unbalanced class probabilities. Hence PM, which predicts that the first click takes place at position one and has an accuracy of 72.27% on our test data set. AM has an accuracy of 73.5%, while the accuracy of DBN and ICM is 72.7% and 71.7%, respectively. In our model, we predict the display with the maximum click inclination as the first click. This gives an accuracy of 79.59%, a gain of over 8.2% compared to the other models. To better understand the performance of models across different deciles, we plot the accuracy of different models in Figure 5. Note that we consistently outperform all other models across all deciles, with gains for the lower deciles, which are harder to learn, being more significant.

sections.heading: 4.5 Predicting the Entire Click Sequence
sections.text: We calculate the click propensity for each click sequence with the same length as the actual click sequence. We say that our model only predicted the click sequence if we correctly predicted the entire click sequence. Table 3 summarizes the results. Our model gains 8.6% (or 25%) in predicting two-click sequences and 3.4% (or 37%) in predicting three-click sequences over DBN (or PM). Model accuracy is comparable when predicting four click sequences that make up only a very small fraction of the data. Although AM is very competitive in predicting the first click, it is unable to accurately predict longer click sequences.

sections.heading: 4.6 Ranking of the Actual Click Sequence
sections.text: In the previous section, we focused on correctly predicting the entire click sequence. Here, we focus on how we classify the actual click sequences based on the log probability. To do this, we calculate the log probability for all permutations of click sequences. We then sort the click sequences based on the calculated log probability and check the rank of the actual click sequence in this list. Table 4 summarizes our results. As shown in Table 1, our model ranks the actual click sequence on average among the top 3 or 4 of all possible permutations of the click sequence. Figure 7 shows how the ranking of the actual click sequence varies across different query deciles. As shown in Table 1, longer click sequences are more common in the lower deciles, and therefore our model has more data to learn in those deciles. Consequently, the average rank of the actual click sequence, as predicted by our model for two, four and three clicks, is lower in the lower deciles.

sections.heading: 4.7 Predicting Top Clicks
sections.text: Here we ignore the order and focus on understanding whether our model is capable of predicting the positions of the clicks in two- and three-click sessions. Table 5 shows that we outperform all other models in predicting the top 2 and 3-click positions.

sections.heading: 4.8 Predicting Reverse Click Sequences
sections.text: In our last experiment, we focus only on those sessions in which at least one click pair was observed in reverse order (reverse-click sessions); as before, we focus only on accuracy (table 6), the rank of the actual click sequence (table 7), and the accuracy of predicting the position of the top clicks (table 8); Figure 9 shows the accuracy and rank of the actual click sequence for different deciles; and Figure 10 shows the accuracy of predicting click positions in two and three click sessions. As expected, our model prediction accuracy for reverse-click sessions is low, as reverse-click sessions account for only about 30% of multi-click sessions; although our accuracy is lower than the attractiveness model, our model ranks the actual reverse-click sequences in the top 5 of all possible permutations of the click sequence; our model performs all other models in most experiments and still achieves a better ranking order than the actual click sequence even when observed in reverse-click sequence.

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: We have introduced a new multiple-click model for modeling how users interact with and click on sponsored search results. Our model can handle reverse-click sequences and outperforms other models in a range of different metrics in a comprehensive empirical evaluation. Online-sponsored search results are evaluated using a generic second-price auction mechanism (GSP) based on the assumption that clicks on ads are independent of each other. We are currently working on developing price mechanisms that take clicking behavior into account in our model. Our efforts also aim to improve the accuracy of our model's reverse-click prediction by using stronger priorities.Finally, we are working on making our model robust against others.APPENDIX

referenceMentions.context: Almost all existing click models are designed for organic search, and make the simplifying assumption that users interact with the search results sequentially [12, 13].
Almost all existing click models are designed for organic search, and make the simplifying assumption that users interact with the search results sequentially [12, 13].
Perhaps, eye tracking studies [9] which are often used to support the linear scan assumption in organic search may not apply to sponsored search.

Like in previous work [15, 16, 5] we also assume a separable model, that is, the user propensity for clicking on a search result is a product of the probability of examining that position and the attractiveness of the document displayed at that position.

Like in previous work [15, 16, 5] we also assume a separable model, that is, the user propensity for clicking on a search result is a product of the probability of examining that position and the attractiveness of the document displayed at that position.

Like in previous work [15, 16, 5] we also assume a separable model, that is, the user propensity for clicking on a search result is a product of the probability of examining that position and the attractiveness of the document displayed at that position.
This is the so-called examination hypothesis [15] or separability assumption [1].
This is the so-called examination hypothesis [15] or separability assumption [1].
The cascade model [6] assumes that users scan the documents from top to bottom without skipping, that is, users examine the ads sequentially:
The cascade model [6] further assumes that users examine documents until they find an appropriate one, and then abandon the search after the first click:
The dependent click model (DCM) [11] extends this to multi-click sessions, by modifying (3) to
The user browsing model (UBM) [7] extends the DCM by assuming that the examination probability depends on the last clicked position in the same query session.
The Bayesian browsing model (BBM) [14] models relevance P (Ci = 1 | di, Ei = 1) as a random variable, and uses a Bayesian approach to estimate its value.
The dynamic Bayesian network (DBN) [4] model differs from the above click models in two important ways.
First, it distinguishes between attractiveness (also called perceived relevance or pre-click relevance in literature [16]) and post-click relevance.
For simplicity, one can set λi−1 = λ for all i [4], or like in the DCM estimate λi−1 from empirical probabilities.
Recently [3] extended the DBN by learning a per-query fatigue parameter and adding a variable to indicate if the user is likely to interact with sponsored search results or directly skip over them.
A related model to DBN is the click chain model (CCM) [10].
Some recent work [18] has focused on incorporating revisiting behaviors into click models.
However, the temporal hidden click model (THCM) proposed by the authors of [18] does not distinguish between attractiveness and post-click relevance.
Externalities [8] refer to the observation that the click on a document also depends on the quality of other documents presented on the same search result page.
For instance, [17] proposed a conditional random fields based model to click prediction to consider the externalities.
, [19] considers externalities but restrict their attention to sessions with just two ads.
On the other hand, [16] showed that the relevance of a document at a position is not constant and it is affected by the clicks in other positions.
In the context of news recommendation, [2] extended the basic DBN model to take into account a sub-modular information gain score, which affects the relevance of a document.
This was found via crossvalidation, based on the recommendation of [4].
Independent Click Model (ICM): Since the cascade model [6] can only handle single click sessions, one can extended it by setting the user perseverance parameter λ in (4) to one [11].
Independent Click Model (ICM): Since the cascade model [6] can only handle single click sessions, one can extended it by setting the user perseverance parameter λ in (4) to one [11].
Since other models do not distinguish between attractiveness and post-click relevance, we will only compare our algorithm with the dynamic Bayesian network (DBN) model of [4].
Following [4] we rank these (q, d) pairs using a score which is calculated as θd × ρd (attractiveness times post-click relevance).

metadata.abstractText: Click models are an important tool for leveraging user feedback, and are used by commercial search engines for surfacing relevant search results. However, existing click models are lacking in two aspects. First, they do not share information across search results when computing attractiveness. Second, they assume that users interact with the search results sequentially. Based on our analysis of the click logs of a commercial search engine, we observe that the sequential scan assumption does not always hold, especially for sponsored search results. To overcome the above two limitations, we propose a new click model. Our key insight is that sharing information across search results helps in identifying important words or key-phrases which can then be used to accurately compute attractiveness of a search result. Furthermore, we argue that the click probability of a position as well as its attractiveness changes during a user session and depends on the user’s past click experience. Our model seamlessly incorporates the effect of externalities (quality of other search results displayed in response to a user query), user fatigue, as well as pre and post-click relevance of a sponsored search result. We propose an efficient one-pass inference scheme and empirically evaluate the performance of our model via extensive experiments using the click logs of a large commercial search engine.
